soln_description:
Prove that for $y_{i}=\frac{1}{1+x_{i}}(i=1,2, \cdots, n)$, thus $x_{i}=\frac{1}{y_{i}}-1$, and $\sum_{i=1}^{n} y_{i}=1$, we have
$$\begin{array}{l}
\sum_{i=1}^{n} \frac{x_{i}}{n-1+x_{i}^{2}} \sum_{i=1}^{n-1+\left(\frac{1}{y_{i}}-1\right)^{2}}=\sum_{i=1}^{n} \frac{y_{i}-y_{i}^{2}}{n y_{i}^{2}-2 y_{i}+1}= \\
\frac{1}{n} \cdot \sum_{i=1}^{n} \frac{n y_{i}-n y_{i}^{2}}{n y_{i}^{2}-2 y_{i}+1}= \\
\frac{1}{n}\left(\sum_{i=1}^{n}\left(-1+\frac{(n-2) y_{i}+1}{n y_{i}^{2}-2 y_{i}+1}\right)=\right. \\
-1+\frac{1}{n} \cdot \sum_{i=1}^{n} \frac{(n-2) y_{i}+1}{n\left(y_{i}-\frac{1}{n}\right)^{2}+1-\frac{1}{n}} \leqslant \\
-1+\frac{1}{n} \cdot \sum_{i=1}^{n} \frac{(n-2) y_{i}+1}{1-\frac{1}{n}}= \\
-1+\frac{1}{n} \cdot \frac{n-2+n}{1-\frac{1}{n}}=-1+\frac{2 n-2}{n-1}=1
\end{array}$$
informal_statement: Example 12 Let $x_{1}, x_{2}, \cdots, x_{n} \geqslant 0$ satisfy $\sum_{i=1}^{n} \frac{1}{1+x_{i}^{2}}=1$, prove that: $\sum_{i=1}^{n} \frac{x_{i}}{n-1+x^{2}} \leq 1$
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

open Real

/- Example 12 Let $x_{1}, x_{2}, \cdots, x_{n} \geqslant 0$ satisfy $\sum_{i=1}^{n} \frac{1}{1+x_{i}^{2}}=1$, prove that: $\sum_{i=1}^{n} \frac{x_{i}}{n-1+x^{2}} \leq 1$ -/
theorem inequalities_602143 (n : ℕ) (hn : 0 < n) (x : Fin n → ℝ)
    (hx : ∀ i, 0 ≤ x i) (h : ∑ i, 1 / (1 + (x i) ^ 2) = 1) :
    ∑ i, x i / (n - 1 + (x i) ^ 2) ≤ 1 := by

soln_description:
[Proof] Let the initial quadruple be $(a, b, c, d)$, and after pressing the button $n$ times, the resulting quadruple is $\left(a_{n}, b_{n}, c_{n}, d_{n}\right)$. Clearly,
$$a_{n}+b_{n}+c_{n}+d_{n}=0 \text {, for any } n \geqslant 1 \text {. }$$

Let $s_{n}=a_{n}^{2}+b_{n}^{2}+c_{n}^{2}+d_{n}^{2}$, and by the fact that $a, b, c, d$ are not all equal, we have $s_{1}>0$. When $n>1$,
$$\begin{aligned}
s_{n}= & \left(a_{n-1}-b_{n-1}\right)^{2}+\left(b_{n-1}-c_{n-1}\right)^{2}+\left(c_{n-1}-d_{n-1}\right)^{2}+\left(d_{n-1}-\right. \\
& \left.a_{n-1}\right)^{2} \\
= & 2\left(a_{n-1}^{2}+b_{n-1}^{2}+c_{n-1}^{2}+d_{n-1}^{2}\right)-2\left(a_{n-1} b_{n-1}+b_{n-1} c_{n-1}+\right. \\
& \left.c_{n-1} d_{n-1}+d_{n-1} a_{n-1}\right) .
\end{aligned}$$

Also, $0=\left(a_{n-1}+b_{n-1}+c_{n-1}+d_{n-1}\right)^{2}=a_{n-1}^{2}+b_{n-1}^{2}+c_{n-1}^{2}+d_{n-1}^{2}+$
$$\begin{array}{l}
2\left(a_{n-1} b_{n-1}+a_{n-1} c_{n-1}+a_{n-1} d_{n-1}+b_{n-1} c_{n-1}+b_{n-1} d_{n-1}+\right. \\
\left.c_{n-1} d_{n-1}\right)
\end{array}$$

Therefore, $\square$
$$\begin{aligned}
s_{n} & =3\left(a_{n-1}^{2}+b_{n-1}^{2}+c_{n-1}^{2}+d_{n-1}^{2}\right)+2 a_{n-1} c_{n-1}+2 b_{n-1} d_{n-1} \\
& \geqslant 2\left(a_{n-1}^{2}+b_{n-1}^{2}+c_{n-1}^{2}+d_{n-1}^{2}\right)=2 s_{n-1} .
\end{aligned}$$

Thus, $s_{n} \geqslant 2^{n-1} s_{1}$, for any $n \geqslant 1$.
From this, we can deduce that there exists a natural number $n_{0}$, such that when $n \geqslant n_{0}$,
$$s_{n}>36 \times 1985^{2},$$

Therefore, when $n \geqslant n_{0}$,
$$\left|a_{n}\right|+\left|b_{n}\right|+\left|c_{n}\right|+\left|d_{n}\right| \geqslant \sqrt{s_{n}}>6 \times 1985 \text {. }$$

By (1), we know that the sum of the positive numbers among $a_{n}, b_{n}, c_{n}, d_{n}$ is $>3 \times 1985$, and since $a_{n}, b_{n}, c_{n}, d_{n}$ have at most three positive numbers, at least one of them must be greater than 1985.
informal_statement: 8. 152 The students of the school mathematics group made a calculator, which can transform a quadruple $(a, b, c, d)$ into $(a-b, b-c, c-d, d-a)$ when a button is pressed. Prove that if the numbers in the initial quadruple are not all equal, then after pressing the button a finite number of times, the numbers in the resulting quadruple will always have at least one greater than 1985.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- 8. 152 The students of the school mathematics group made a calculator, which can transform a quadruple $(a, b, c, d)$ into $(a-b, b-c, c-d, d-a)$ when a button is pressed. Prove that if the numbers in the initial quadruple are not all equal, then after pressing the button a finite number of times, the numbers in the resulting quadruple will always have at least one greater than 1985. -/
theorem algebra_602939 (a b c d : ℝ) (h : ¬(a = b ∧ b = c ∧ c = d)) :
    ∃ n, (a - b) * 4 ^ n > 1985 ∨ (b - c) * 4 ^ n > 1985 ∨ (c - d) * 4 ^ n > 1985 ∨
    (d - a) * 4 ^ n > 1985 := by

soln_description:
9. Answer: 4
Solution. Since $2002 \equiv 4(\bmod 9) \quad 4^{3} \equiv 1(\bmod 9)$ and $2002=667 \times 3+1$, it follows that $2002^{2002} \equiv 4^{667 \times 3+1} \equiv 4(\bmod 9)$. Observe that for positive integers $x$, the possible residues modulo 9 for $x^{3}$ are $0 \pm 1$. Therefore, none of the following
$$
x_{1}^{3} x_{1}^{3}+x_{2}^{3} \quad x_{1}^{3}+x_{2}^{3}+x_{3}^{3}
$$
can have a residue of 4 modulo 9 . However, since $2002=10^{3}+10^{3}+1^{3}+1^{3}$, it follows that
$$
\begin{aligned}
2002^{2002} & =2002 \cdot\left(2002^{667}\right)^{3} \\
& =\left(10^{3}+10^{3}+1^{3}+1^{3}\right)\left(2002^{667}\right)^{3} \\
& =\left(10 \cdot 2002^{667}\right)^{3}+\left(10 \cdot 2002^{667}\right)^{3}+\left(2002^{667}\right)^{3}+\left(2002^{667}\right)^{3}
\end{aligned}
$$

This shows that $x_{1}^{3}+x_{2}^{3}+x_{3}^{3}+x_{4}^{4}=2002^{2002}$ is indeed solvable. Hence the least integral value of $n$ is 4 .
informal_statement:
9. Find the least positive integral value of $n$ for which the equation
$$
x_{1}^{3}+x_{2}^{3}+\cdots+x_{n}^{3}=2002^{2002}
$$
has integer solutions $\left(x_{1}, x_{2}, x_{3}, \cdots, x_{n}\right)$.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- 9. Find the least positive integral value of $n$ for which the equation
$$
x_{1}^{3}+x_{2}^{3}+\cdots+x_{n}^{3}=2002^{2002}
$$
has integer solutions $\left(x_{1}, x_{2}, x_{3}, \cdots, x_{n}\right)$. -/
theorem number_theory_101758 :
    IsLeast {n | ∃ x : Fin n → ℤ, ∑ i : Fin n, (x i)^3 = 2002^2002} 4 := by

soln_description: 18. Answer: 1001. $\frac{n^{3}+2011}{n+10}=n^{2}-10 n+100+\frac{1011}{n+10}$. This is an integer if and only if $(n+10) \mid 1011$. The maximum value of $n$ is $1011-10=1001$.
informal_statement: 18. Find the largest positive integer $n$ such that $n+10$ is a divisor of $n^{3}+2011$.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- 18. Find the largest positive integer $n$ such that $n+10$ is a divisor of $n^{3}+2011$. -/
theorem number_theory_99718 :
    IsGreatest {n : ℕ | 0 < n ∧ (n + 10) ∣ (n ^ 3 + 2011)} 1001 := by

soln_description:
To prove the inequality for positive \(a, b, c, d\):
\[
(a + b)(b + c)(c + d)(d + a)(1 + \sqrt[4]{abcd})^{4} \geq 16abcd(1 + a)(1 + b)(1 + c)(1 + d)
\]

1. **Initial Inequality Setup:**
   We start with the given inequality:
   \[
   (a + b)(b + c)(c + d)(d + a)(1 + \sqrt[4]{abcd})^{4} \geq 16abcd(1 + a)(1 + b)(1 + c)(1 + d)
   \]

2. **Applying AM-GM Inequality:**
   By the Arithmetic Mean-Geometric Mean (AM-GM) inequality, we know:
   \[
   a + b \geq 2\sqrt{ab}, \quad b + c \geq 2\sqrt{bc}, \quad c + d \geq 2\sqrt{cd}, \quad d + a \geq 2\sqrt{da}
   \]
   Multiplying these inequalities, we get:
   \[
   (a + b)(b + c)(c + d)(d + a) \geq 16\sqrt{abcd}
   \]

3. **Simplifying the Left-Hand Side:**
   Consider the term \((1 + \sqrt[4]{abcd})^{4}\). By the binomial theorem, we have:
   \[
   (1 + \sqrt[4]{abcd})^{4} = 1 + 4\sqrt[4]{abcd} + 6\sqrt[2]{abcd} + 4(abcd)^{3/4} + abcd
   \]
   Since \(\sqrt[4]{abcd} \geq 1\) for positive \(a, b, c, d\), it follows that:
   \[
   (1 + \sqrt[4]{abcd})^{4} \geq 16
   \]

4. **Combining the Results:**
   Combining the results from steps 2 and 3, we get:
   \[
   (a + b)(b + c)(c + d)(d + a)(1 + \sqrt[4]{abcd})^{4} \geq 16\sqrt{abcd} \cdot 16 = 256\sqrt{abcd}
   \]

5. **Right-Hand Side Simplification:**
   Now, consider the right-hand side of the original inequality:
   \[
   16abcd(1 + a)(1 + b)(1 + c)(1 + d)
   \]
   Using AM-GM again, we have:
   \[
   1 + a \geq 2\sqrt{a}, \quad 1 + b \geq 2\sqrt{b}, \quad 1 + c \geq 2\sqrt{c}, \quad 1 + d \geq 2\sqrt{d}
   \]
   Multiplying these inequalities, we get:
   \[
   (1 + a)(1 + b)(1 + c)(1 + d) \geq 16\sqrt{abcd}
   \]
   Therefore:
   \[
   16abcd(1 + a)(1 + b)(1 + c)(1 + d) \geq 256abcd
   \]

6. **Final Comparison:**
   Comparing the left-hand side and the right-hand side, we have:
   \[
   256\sqrt{abcd} \geq 256abcd
   \]
   Since \(\sqrt{abcd} \geq abcd\) for positive \(a, b, c, d\), the inequality holds true.

\(\blacksquare\)
informal_statement:
For positive $ a, b, c, d$ prove that 
$ (a \plus{} b)(b \plus{} c)(c \plus{} d)(d \plus{} a)(1 \plus{} \sqrt [4]{abcd})^{4}\geq16abcd(1 \plus{} a)(1 \plus{} b)(1 \plus{} c)(1 \plus{} d)$
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- For positive $ a, b, c, d$ prove that 
$ (a \plus{} b)(b \plus{} c)(c \plus{} d)(d \plus{} a)(1 \plus{} \sqrt [4]{abcd})^{4}\geq16abcd(1 \plus{} a)(1 \plus{} b)(1 \plus{} c)(1 \plus{} d)$ -/
theorem inequalities_44022 (a b c d : ℝ) (ha : 0 < a) (hb : 0 < b) (hc : 0 < c) (hd : 0 < d) :
    (a + b) * (b + c) * (c + d) * (d + a) * (1 + (a * b * c * d) ^ ((1 : ℝ) / 4)) ^ 4 ≥
    16 * a * b * c * d * (1 + a) * (1 + b) * (1 + c) * (1 + d) := by

informal_statement: Grandma gave Bryce and Carter some raisins. Bryce received 6 more raisins than Carter, and Carter received half the number of raisins Bryce received. How many raisins did Bryce receive?
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- Grandma gave Bryce and Carter some raisins. Bryce received 6 more raisins than Carter, and Carter received half the number of raisins Bryce received. How many raisins did Bryce receive? -/
theorem algebra_16833 {b c : ℕ} (h₀ : b = c + 6) (h₁ : c = b / 2) :
    b = 12 := by

informal_statement:
In this problem, $m$ and $n$ are integers.

If $m\equiv 4\pmod{14}$ and $m-n\equiv 10\pmod{14}$, then what is the remainder when $m+n$ is divided by $14$?
informal_proof:
We are given two congruences for integers $m$ and $n$:
1. $m \equiv 4 \pmod{14}$
2. $m - n \equiv 10 \pmod{14}$

Our goal is to determine the remainder of $m+n$ when divided by $14$. We will do this by finding the value to which $m+n$ is congruent modulo $14$.

From the second congruence, we can use the properties of modular arithmetic to solve for $n$. Subtracting $m$ from both sides gives:
$$-n \equiv 10 - m \pmod{14}$$
Multiplying both sides by $-1$, we get:
$$n \equiv m - 10 \pmod{14}$$
Now, we can substitute the first given congruence, $m \equiv 4 \pmod{14}$, into this relationship:
$$n \equiv 4 - 10 \pmod{14}$$
$$n \equiv -6 \pmod{14}$$
To express this with a positive remainder, we can add $14$ to $-6$:
$$n \equiv -6 + 14 \pmod{14}$$
$$n \equiv 8 \pmod{14}$$
Now we have the congruence classes for both $m$ and $n$. We can find the congruence for their sum by adding the respective congruences:
$$m + n \equiv 4 + 8 \pmod{14}$$
$$m + n \equiv 12 \pmod{14}$$
This result means that $m+n$ has the same remainder as $12$ when divided by $14$. Since $0 \le 12 < 14$, the remainder is $12$.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- In this problem, $m$ and $n$ are integers.

If $m\equiv 4\pmod{14}$ and $m-n\equiv 10\pmod{14}$, then what is the remainder when $m+n$ is divided by $14$? -/
theorem number_theory_22812 (m n : ℤ) (h₀ : m ≡ 4 [ZMOD 14]) (h₁ : m - n ≡ 10 [ZMOD 14]) :
    m + n ≡ 12 [ZMOD 14] := by
formal_proof:
import Mathlib

theorem number_theory_22812 (m n : ℤ) (h₀ : m ≡ 4 [ZMOD 14]) (h₁ : m - n ≡ 10 [ZMOD 14]) :
    m + n ≡ 12 [ZMOD 14] := by
  norm_num [Int.ModEq] at h₀ h₁ ⊢
  omega

soln_description: Solution. $1+\frac{2}{9}=\frac{11}{9}$ of the planned number of students have registered. $\frac{3}{11}$ of $\frac{11}{9}$ have canceled, which means $\frac{3}{11} \cdot \frac{11}{9}=\frac{1}{3}$ of the planned number have canceled. Those who went on the trip are $\frac{11}{9}-\frac{1}{3}=\frac{11-3}{9}=\frac{8}{9}$ of the planned number of students. This means, $\frac{1}{9}$ of the planned number is 5 students, from which it follows that 45 students were planned to go on the trip. According to this, 45-5=40 students went on the trip.
informal_statement: Problem 1. The students from the seventh grade of a school are going on a winter trip. $\frac{2}{9}$ more students registered than planned. Before departure, $\frac{3}{11}$ of the registered students canceled, so 5 fewer students went on the trip than planned. How many students went on the trip?
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- Problem 1. The students from the seventh grade of a school are going on a winter trip. $\frac{2}{9}$ more students registered than planned. Before departure, $\frac{3}{11}$ of the registered students canceled, so 5 fewer students went on the trip than planned. How many students went on the trip? -/
theorem algebra_238579 (n : ℕ) (h₀ : n ≠ 0) (h₁ : (2 / 9 : ℚ) * n = (3 / 11 : ℚ) * n - 5) :
    n = 40 := by

informal_statement: Let $p$ be a prime number of the form $p = 3k + 2$ for some nonnegative integer $k$. Suppose that $p$ divides the expression $a^4 + a^3 + 7a^2 + 9a + 21$ for some positive integer $a$. Prove that $p = 17$.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- Let $p$ be a prime number of the form $p = 3k + 2$ for some nonnegative integer $k$. Suppose that $p$ divides the expression $a^4 + a^3 + 7a^2 + 9a + 21$ for some positive integer $a$. Prove that $p = 17$. -/
theorem number_theory_2752 (p k a : ℕ) (hp : p.Prime) (hk : p = 3 * k + 2)
    (hpa : p ∣ a ^ 4 + a ^ 3 + 7 * a ^ 2 + 9 * a + 21) (ha : 0 < a) :
    p = 17 := by

soln_description:
Prove that since $G_{n} \leqslant A_{n}$, we have
$$\begin{aligned}
& \left(1+a_{1}\right)\left(1+a_{2}\right) \cdots\left(1+a_{n}\right) \\
\leqslant & \left(\frac{n+a_{1}+a_{2}+\cdots+a_{n}}{n}\right)^{n}=\left(1+\frac{S}{n}\right)^{n} \\
= & 1+\mathrm{C}_{n}^{1}\left(\frac{S}{n}\right)+\mathrm{C}_{n}^{2}\left(\frac{S}{n}\right)^{2}+\cdots+\mathrm{C}_{n}^{m}\left(\frac{S}{n}\right)^{m}+\cdots+\mathrm{C}_{n}^{n}\left(\frac{S}{n}\right)^{n}
\end{aligned}$$

Since $n!=(n-m)!(n-m+1) \cdots n \leqslant(n-m)!n^{m}$,
we have
$$\mathrm{C}_{n}^{m}\left(\frac{S}{n}\right)^{m}=\frac{n!}{m!(n-m)!} \cdot \frac{1}{n^{m}} S^{m} \leqslant \frac{S^{m}}{m!}$$

Thus, the proposition holds.
informal_statement:
Example 7 Let $a_{1}, a_{2}, \cdots, a_{n} \in \mathbf{R}^{+}, S=a_{1}+a_{2}+\cdots+a_{n}$. Prove:
$$\left(1+a_{1}\right)\left(1+a_{2}\right) \cdots\left(1+a_{n}\right) \leqslant 1+S+\frac{S^{2}}{2!}+\cdots+\frac{S^{n}}{n!} .$$
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

open Real

/- Example 7 Let $a_{1}, a_{2}, \cdots, a_{n} \in \mathbf{R}^{+}, S=a_{1}+a_{2}+\cdots+a_{n}$. Prove:
$$\left(1+a_{1}\right)\left(1+a_{2}\right) \cdots\left(1+a_{n}\right) \leqslant 1+S+\frac{S^{2}}{2!}+\cdots+\frac{S^{n}}{n!} .$$ -/
theorem inequalities_601331 (n : ℕ) (hn : 0 < n) (a : Fin n → ℝ)
    (ha : ∀ i, 0 < a i) (S : ℝ) (hS : S = ∑ i, a i) :
    ∏ i, (1 + a i) ≤ ∑ j in Finset.range (n + 1), (S ^ j) / (Nat.factorial j) := by

soln_description: We put $P$ in canonical form: $P=a(x-b)^{2}+c$. We translate by $b$ along the x-axis, by -c along the y-axis, and apply a homothety with ratio $\frac{1}{\sqrt{a}}$.
informal_statement:
Let $a, b, c \in \mathbb{R}$, with $a \neq 0$, and consider the graph of the function $\mathrm{P}(\mathrm{x})=$ $a x^{2}+b x+c$. Show that by performing a homothety and a translation, one can obtain the graph of the function $Q(x)=x^{2}$.

Remark 3.34. It follows that given a polynomial of degree 2, one can easily determine whether it has real roots, and if so, provide their expression. This is quite remarkable: one can show that there exist polynomials of degree 5 whose real roots cannot be expressed using square roots, cube roots, etc. However, if $\mathrm{P}(\mathrm{x})$ is a polynomial of degree 3 and if one finds an obvious root $a$ (for example $a=1,2,-1,-2, \ldots$), then one can perform the Euclidean division of $P$ by $x-a$. It follows that there exists $Q$, a polynomial of degree 2, such that $P(x)=Q(x)(x-a)$. But $Q$ is of degree 2, and the above applies. The moral of this is that if one finds an obvious root of a polynomial of degree 3, then one will be able to know all its roots. As an illustration, one can look for the following exercise.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- Let $a, b, c \in \mathbb{R}$, with $a \neq 0$, and consider the graph of the function $\mathrm{P}(\mathrm{x})=$ $a x^{2}+b x+c$. Show that by performing a homothety and a translation, one can obtain the graph of the function $Q(x)=x^{2}$.

Remark 3.34. It follows that given a polynomial of degree 2, one can easily determine whether it has real roots, and if so, provide their expression. This is quite remarkable: one can show that there exist polynomials of degree 5 whose real roots cannot be expressed using square roots, cube roots, etc. However, if $\mathrm{P}(\mathrm{x})$ is a polynomial of degree 3 and if one finds an obvious root $a$ (for example $a=1,2,-1,-2, \ldots$), then one can perform the Euclidean division of $P$ by $x-a$. It follows that there exists $Q$, a polynomial of degree 2, such that $P(x)=Q(x)(x-a)$. But $Q$ is of degree 2, and the above applies. The moral of this is that if one finds an obvious root of a polynomial of degree 3, then one will be able to know all its roots. As an illustration, one can look for the following exercise. -/
theorem algebra_120930 (a b c : ℝ) (ha : a ≠ 0) (P : ℝ → ℝ) (hP : P = fun x => a * x ^ 2 + b * x + c)
    (Q : ℝ → ℝ) (hQ : Q = fun x => x ^ 2) :
    ∃ f g : ℝ → ℝ, (∀ x, P x = Q (f x)) ∧ (∀ x, f x = g x) := by

soln_description:
(1) From $a_{n}^{3}+\frac{a_{n}}{n}=1$, we get $00$, hence $a_{n+1}-a_{n}>0$, which means $a_{n+1}>a_{n}$.
(2) Since $a_{n}\left(a_{n}^{2}+\frac{1}{n}\right)=1$, it follows that $a_{n}=\frac{1}{a_{n}^{2}+\frac{1}{n}}>\frac{1}{1+\frac{1}{n}}=\frac{n}{n+1}$, thus
$$
\begin{array}{l}
\frac{1}{(n+1)^{2} a_{n}}<\frac{1}{n(n+1)}, \\
\sum_{i=1}^{n} \frac{1}{(i+1)^{2} a_{i}}<\sum_{i=1}^{n} \frac{1}{i(i+1)}=\sum_{i=1}^{n}\left(\frac{1}{i}-\frac{1}{i+1}\right)=1-\frac{1}{n+1}=\frac{n}{n+1}<a_{n}, \\
\text { hence } \sum_{i=1}^{n} \frac{1}{(i+1)^{2} a_{i}}<a_{n} .
\end{array}
$$
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

open Real

/- 4K $* \star$ For any positive integer $n$, let $a_{n}$ be the real root of the equation $x^{3}+\frac{x}{n}=1$. Prove:
(1) $a_{n+1}>a_{n}$;
(2) $\sum_{i=1}^{n} \frac{1}{(i+1)^{2} a_{i}}<a_{n}$. -/
theorem algebra_164345 {a : ℕ → ℝ} (ha : ∀ n, 0 < n → a n ^ 3 + a n / n = 1) :
    StrictMono a ∧ (∀ n, 0 < n → ∑ i in Finset.Icc 1 n, 1 / ((i + 1) ^ 2 * a i) < a n) := by

soln_description:
Solution

a) If $a_{1}=2$ and $r=3$, we have

$$
\begin{aligned}
& a_{2}=a_{1}+3=5 \\
& a_{3}=a_{2}+3=8 \\
& a_{4}=a_{3}+3=11
\end{aligned}
$$

b) Let $a_{1}=d$ and $r$ be the common difference. Then, we have:

$$
\begin{aligned}
& a_{1}=d, \quad a_{2}=d+r, \quad a_{3}=d+2 r, \quad a_{4}=d+3 r, \quad a_{5}=d+4 r, \quad a_{6}=d+5 r \\
& a_{7}=d+6 r, \quad a_{8}=d+7 r, \quad a_{9}=d+8 r, \quad a_{10}=d+9 r, \quad a_{11}=d+10 r .
\end{aligned}
$$

Therefore,

$$
\begin{aligned}
a_{4}+a_{7}+a_{10} & =(d+3 r)+(d+6 r)+(d+9 r) \\
217 & =3(d+6 r) \\
a_{5}+a_{6}+a_{7}+a_{8}+a_{9}+a_{10}+a_{11} & =(d+4 r)+(d+5 r)+\ldots+(d+10 r) \\
553 & =7(d+7 r)
\end{aligned}
$$

Consequently,

$$
\left\{\begin{aligned}
d+6 r & =217 / 3=72.333 \approx 72 \\
d+7 r & =553 / 7=79
\end{aligned}\right.
$$

Solving the above system, we get $r=10$ and $d=9$. Thus, $a_{11}=d+10 r=109$. 

(Note: The original text had a minor calculation error, as 217 / 3 = 72.333, which should be rounded to 72 for consistency with the integer solution. However, the final answer remains correct as $a_{11}=109$.)
informal_statement:
An arithmetic progression, commonly referred to as an A.P., is a sequence in which each term, starting from the second, is equal to the sum of the previous term and a fixed value \( r \) called the common difference or the ratio of the progression. For example, the sequence below is an arithmetic progression with the first term 3 and a common difference of 4.

\[
a_{1}=3, a_{2}=7, a_{3}=11, a_{4}=15, a_{5}=19, a_{6}=23, a_{7}=27, a_{8}=31, a_{9}=35, \ldots
\]

Notice that we denote the number at position \( i \) by the symbol \( a_{i} \).

a) If the first term of an arithmetic progression is 2 and its common difference is 3, what is the value of the fourth term?

b) João's teacher asked him to calculate the eleventh term of an arithmetic progression. Unfortunately, he forgot the first term and the common difference. The only information he remembered was:

\[
\begin{aligned}
a_{4}+a_{7}+a_{10} & =207 \\
a_{5}+a_{6}+a_{7}+a_{8}+a_{9}+a_{10}+a_{11} & =553
\end{aligned}
\]

What is the value of the eleventh term?
informal_proof:
Let the sequence `(a n)` for `n ∈ ℕ` be an arithmetic progression with initial term `a 0` and common difference `r`. The general term is given by the formula `a n = a 0 + n * r` for all `n ∈ ℕ`.

We are given two conditions:
1. `a 3 + a 6 + a 9 = 207`
2. `a 4 + a 5 + a 6 + a 7 + a 8 + a 9 + a 10 = 553`

Our goal is to determine the value of `a 10`.

First, we use the general formula to express the terms in the first equation in terms of `a 0` and `r`:
- `a 3 = a 0 + 3 * r`
- `a 6 = a 0 + 6 * r`
- `a 9 = a 0 + 9 * r`

Substituting these into the first equation yields:
`(a 0 + 3 * r) + (a 0 + 6 * r) + (a 0 + 9 * r) = 207`
By collecting like terms, we get:
`3 * a 0 + 18 * r = 207`
Dividing the equation by 3 simplifies it to:
`(1) a 0 + 6 * r = 69`

Next, we express the terms in the second equation in terms of `a 0` and `r`:
- `a 4 = a 0 + 4 * r`
- `a 5 = a 0 + 5 * r`
- `a 6 = a 0 + 6 * r`
- `a 7 = a 0 + 7 * r`
- `a 8 = a 0 + 8 * r`
- `a 9 = a 0 + 9 * r`
- `a 10 = a 0 + 10 * r`

Substituting these into the second equation gives:
`(a 0 + 4 * r) + (a 0 + 5 * r) + (a 0 + 6 * r) + (a 0 + 7 * r) + (a 0 + 8 * r) + (a 0 + 9 * r) + (a 0 + 10 * r) = 553`
This sum contains 7 terms involving `a 0`. The sum of the coefficients of `r` is `4 + 5 + 6 + 7 + 8 + 9 + 10 = 49`. Thus, the equation simplifies to:
`(2) 7 * a 0 + 49 * r = 553`

We now have a system of two linear equations with variables `a 0` and `r`:
1. `a 0 + 6 * r = 69`
2. `7 * a 0 + 49 * r = 553`

From equation (1), we can express `a 0` as `a 0 = 69 - 6 * r`. Substituting this into equation (2):
`7 * (69 - 6 * r) + 49 * r = 553`
`483 - 42 * r + 49 * r = 553`
`483 + 7 * r = 553`
`7 * r = 553 - 483`
`7 * r = 70`
This gives `r = 10`.

Now, we substitute `r = 10` back into equation (1) to find `a 0`:
`a 0 + 6 * 10 = 69`
`a 0 + 60 = 69`
This gives `a 0 = 9`.

Finally, we can compute `a 10` using its formula and the values we have found for `a 0` and `r`:
`a 10 = a 0 + 10 * r`
`a 10 = 9 + 10 * 10`
`a 10 = 9 + 100`
`a 10 = 109`

Thus, the value of `a 10` is 109.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- An arithmetic progression, commonly referred to as an A.P., is a sequence in which each term, starting from the second, is equal to the sum of the previous term and a fixed value \( r \) called the common difference or the ratio of the progression. For example, the sequence below is an arithmetic progression with the first term 3 and a common difference of 4.

\[
a_{1}=3, a_{2}=7, a_{3}=11, a_{4}=15, a_{5}=19, a_{6}=23, a_{7}=27, a_{8}=31, a_{9}=35, \ldots
\]

Notice that we denote the number at position \( i \) by the symbol \( a_{i} \).

a) If the first term of an arithmetic progression is 2 and its common difference is 3, what is the value of the fourth term?

b) João's teacher asked him to calculate the eleventh term of an arithmetic progression. Unfortunately, he forgot the first term and the common difference. The only information he remembered was:

\[
\begin{aligned}
a_{4}+a_{7}+a_{10} & =207 \\
a_{5}+a_{6}+a_{7}+a_{8}+a_{9}+a_{10}+a_{11} & =553
\end{aligned}
\]

What is the value of the eleventh term? -/
theorem algebra_246321 (a : ℕ → ℝ) (r : ℝ) (h₀ : ∀ n, a n = a 0 + r * n)
    (h₁ : a 3 + a 6 + a 9 = 207) (h₂ : a 4 + a 5 + a 6 + a 7 + a 8 + a 9 + a 10 = 553) :
    a 10 = 109 := by
formal_proof:
import Mathlib

theorem algebra_246321 (a : ℕ → ℝ) (r : ℝ) (h₀ : ∀ n, a n = a 0 + r * n)
    (h₁ : a 3 + a 6 + a 9 = 207) (h₂ : a 4 + a 5 + a 6 + a 7 + a 8 + a 9 + a 10 = 553) :
    a 10 = 109 := by
  have h3 : a 3 = a 0 + 3 * r := by
    rw [h₀ 3]
    ring
  have h6 : a 6 = a 0 + 6 * r := by
    rw [h₀ 6]
    ring
  have h9 : a 9 = a 0 + 9 * r := by
    rw [h₀ 9]
    ring
  rw [h3, h6, h9] at h₁
  have eq1 : a 0 + 6 * r = 69 := by
    linarith
  have h4 : a 4 = a 0 + 4 * r := by
    rw [h₀ 4]
    ring
  have h5 : a 5 = a 0 + 5 * r := by
    rw [h₀ 5]
    ring
  have h7 : a 7 = a 0 + 7 * r := by
    rw [h₀ 7]
    ring
  have h8 : a 8 = a 0 + 8 * r := by
    rw [h₀ 8]
    ring
  have h10 : a 10 = a 0 + 10 * r := by
    rw [h₀ 10]
    ring
  rw [h4, h5, h6, h7, h8, h9, h10] at h₂
  have eq2 : 7 * (a 0) + 49 * r = 553 := by
    linarith
  have h_r : r = 10 := by
    nlinarith [eq1, eq2]
  have h_a0 : a 0 = 9 := by
    linarith [eq1, h_r]
  rw [h10]
  rw [h_a0, h_r]
  norm_num

informal_statement: A rectangular room has a perimeter of 42 feet and an area of 108 square feet. What is the length, in feet, of the shorter side?
informal_proof:
Let the dimensions of the rectangular room be `a` and `b`, where `a > 0` and `b > 0`. We are given the following information:
1.  The perimeter is 42 feet: `2 * (a + b) = 42`.
2.  The area is 108 square feet: `a * b = 108`.

Our goal is to find the value of the shorter side, which is `min a b`.

From the perimeter equation, we can simplify by dividing both sides by 2:
`a + b = 21`

From this, we can express `b` in terms of `a`:
`b = 21 - a`

Now, we substitute this expression for `b` into the area equation:
`a * (21 - a) = 108`

Expanding this equation gives:
`21*a - a^2 = 108`

Rearranging the terms, we obtain a quadratic equation in `a`:
`a^2 - 21*a + 108 = 0`

We can solve this quadratic equation by factoring. We look for two numbers that sum to -21 and multiply to 108. These numbers are -9 and -12. Thus, the equation can be factored as:
`(a - 9) * (a - 12) = 0`

For the product of two factors to be zero, at least one of the factors must be zero. This gives us two possible cases for the value of `a`.

**Case 1: `a - 9 = 0`**
In this case, `a = 9`. Using the relation `a + b = 21`, we find the corresponding value for `b`:
`9 + b = 21`, which implies `b = 12`.
The lengths of the sides are 9 and 12. The shorter side is `min(9, 12) = 9`.

**Case 2: `a - 12 = 0`**
In this case, `a = 12`. Using the relation `a + b = 21`, we find the corresponding value for `b`:
`12 + b = 21`, which implies `b = 9`.
The lengths of the sides are 12 and 9. The shorter side is `min(12, 9) = 9`.

In both possible cases, the length of the shorter side of the room is 9 feet.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- A rectangular room has a perimeter of 42 feet and an area of 108 square feet. What is the length, in feet, of the shorter side? -/
theorem algebra_14441 {a b : ℝ} (ha : a > 0) (hb : b > 0)
    (hperim : 2 * (a + b) = 42) (harea : a * b = 108) :
    min a b = 9 := by
formal_proof:
import Mathlib

theorem algebra_14441 {a b : ℝ} (ha : a > 0) (hb : b > 0)
    (hperim : 2 * (a + b) = 42) (harea : a * b = 108) :
    min a b = 9 := by
  have h1 : a + b = 21 := by
    linarith

  -- Derive the quadratic equation in terms of `a`.
  have h3 : a^2 - 21 * a + 108 = 0 := by
    have h4 : b = 21 - a := by linarith
    rw [h4] at harea
    nlinarith
  
  -- Solve the quadratic equation to get (a - 9)(a - 12) = 0
  have h4 : (a - 9) * (a - 12) = 0 := by
    nlinarith [h3]

  cases' (mul_eq_zero.1 h4) with ha1 ha2
  
  · -- Case 1: a - 9 = 0, so a = 9. Then b = 21 - a = 12
    have ha9 : a = 9 := by linarith
    have hb12 : b = 12 := by linarith [h1, ha9]
    rw [ha9, hb12]
    norm_num
  
  · -- Case 2: a - 12 = 0, so a = 12. Then b = 21 - a = 9
    have ha12 : a = 12 := by linarith
    have hb9 : b = 9 := by linarith [h1, ha12]
    rw [ha12, hb9]
    norm_num

soln_description:
14. (1) Since
$$
\begin{array}{l}
(a+c)(b+c)=a b+a c+b c+c^{2} \\
=a b+(a+b+c) c \\
=a b+\frac{1}{a b} \geqslant 2 \sqrt{a b \cdot \frac{1}{a b}}=2,
\end{array}
$$

the equality holds when $a b=1$, so when $a=b=1$, $c=\sqrt{2}-1$, $S$ can take the minimum value 2.
(2) When $S$ takes the minimum value, $a b=1$, thus,
$$
c(a+b+c)=1 \Rightarrow c^{2}+(a+b) c-1=0 \text {. }
$$

Let $t=a+b$. Then $t \geqslant 2 \sqrt{a b}=2$.
Thus, $c=\frac{-t+\sqrt{t^{2}+4}}{2}$ (negative value is discarded).
Since $c=\frac{-t+\sqrt{t^{2}+4}}{2}=\frac{2}{\sqrt{t^{2}+4}+t}$ is monotonically decreasing in $t \in$ $[2,+\infty)$, therefore, when $t=2$, $c$ has the maximum value $\sqrt{2}-1$
informal_statement:
14. Given $a, b, c \in \mathbf{R}_{+}$, satisfying $a b c(a+b+c)=1$.
(1) Find the minimum value of $S=(a+c)(b+c)$;
(2) When $S$ takes the minimum value, find the maximum value of $c$.

保留了源文本的换行和格式。
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- 14. Given $a, b, c \in \mathbf{R}_{+}$, satisfying $a b c(a+b+c)=1$.
(1) Find the minimum value of $S=(a+c)(b+c)$;
(2) When $S$ takes the minimum value, find the maximum value of $c$. -/
theorem algebra_298455 (a b c : ℝ) (ha : 0 < a) (hb : 0 < b) (hc : 0 < c)
    (h : a * b * c * (a + b + c) = 1) :
    (a + c) * (b + c) ≥ √2 - 1 ∧
    ((a + c) * (b + c) = √2 - 1 ↔ c = √2 - 1) := by

soln_description:
To prove that any real solution of \( x^3 + px + q = 0 \), where \( p \) and \( q \) are real numbers, satisfies the inequality \( 4qx \le p^2 \), we can proceed as follows:

1. **Start with the given cubic equation:**
   \[
   x^3 + px + q = 0
   \]

2. **Multiply both sides of the equation by \( 4x \):**
   \[
   4x(x^3 + px + q) = 0
   \]
   This simplifies to:
   \[
   4x^4 + 4px^2 + 4qx = 0
   \]

3. **Rearrange the equation:**
   \[
   4x^4 + 4px^2 + 4qx = 0 \implies 4x^4 + 4px^2 = -4qx
   \]

4. **Add \( p^2 \) to both sides:**
   \[
   4x^4 + 4px^2 + p^2 = p^2 - 4qx
   \]

5. **Recognize the left-hand side as a perfect square:**
   \[
   (2x^2 + p)^2 = p^2 - 4qx
   \]

6. **Since the square of any real number is non-negative, we have:**
   \[
   (2x^2 + p)^2 \ge 0
   \]

7. **Thus, the right-hand side must also be non-negative:**
   \[
   p^2 - 4qx \ge 0
   \]

8. **Rearrange to obtain the desired inequality:**
   \[
   4qx \le p^2
   \]

This completes the proof.

\(\blacksquare\)
informal_statement: Prove that any real solution of $x^3+px+q=0$, where $p,q$ are real numbers, satisfies the inequality $4qx\le p^2$.
informal_proof:
Let $p$, $q$, and $x$ be real numbers satisfying the equation $x^3 + px + q = 0$. We want to show that $4qx \le p^2$.

From the given equation, we can express $q$ in terms of $p$ and $x$:
$$x^3 + px + q = 0 \implies q = -x^3 - px$$

Now, we substitute this expression for $q$ into the inequality we wish to prove:
$$4qx \le p^2$$
$$4(-x^3 - px)x \le p^2$$

Distributing the $4x$ on the left-hand side gives:
$$-4x^4 - 4px^2 \le p^2$$

We can rearrange this inequality by moving all terms to one side:
$$0 \le p^2 + 4px^2 + 4x^4$$

The expression on the right-hand side is a perfect square trinomial. Specifically, it can be factored as:
$$p^2 + 4px^2 + 4x^4 = (p + 2x^2)^2$$

Thus, our inequality is equivalent to:
$$0 \le (p + 2x^2)^2$$

Since $p$ and $x$ are real numbers, the term $p + 2x^2$ is also a real number. The square of any real number is always non-negative. Therefore, the inequality $0 \le (p + 2x^2)^2$ is always true.

This completes the proof that $4qx \le p^2$.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- Prove that any real solution of $x^3+px+q=0$, where $p,q$ are real numbers, satisfies the inequality $4qx\le p^2$. -/
theorem inequalities_65602 (p q : ℝ) (x : ℝ) (hx : x^3 + p * x + q = 0) :
    4 * q * x ≤ p^2 := by
formal_proof:
import Mathlib

theorem inequalities_65602 (p q : ℝ) (x : ℝ) (hx : x^3 + p * x + q = 0) :
    4 * q * x ≤ p^2 := by 
  have h1 : q = -x^3 - p * x := by linarith
  rw [h1]
  nlinarith [sq_nonneg (x^2 * 2 + p), sq_nonneg (x^2 + p), sq_nonneg (x^2 - p)]

soln_description:
$$
=, \because m, n>0, \therefore m+n=5 .
$$

Thus, $p=-(m+n)=-\sqrt{5}, q=mn=1$,
$$
\therefore x^{2}-\sqrt{5} x+1=0 \text {. }
$$
$$
\text { Also } \begin{array}{l} 
x^{3}-(\sqrt{5}-1) x^{2}-(\sqrt{5}-1) x+1994 \\
=\left(x^{3}+1\right)-(\sqrt{5}-1) x(x+1)+1993 \\
=(x+1)\left[\left(x^{2}-x+1\right)-(\sqrt{5}-1) x\right] \\
\quad+1993 \\
=(x+1)\left(x^{2}-\sqrt{5} x+1\right)+1993 \\
= 1993 .
\end{array}
$$
informal_statement: II. (30 points) Given positive numbers $m, n$ are the roots of the quadratic equation $x^{2}+$ $p x+q=0$, and $m^{2}+n^{2}=3, m n=1$. Find the value of the polynomial $x^{3}-(\sqrt{5}-1) x^{2}-(\sqrt{5}-1) x+1994$.
informal_proof:
We are given that `m` and `n` are positive real numbers satisfying the relations `m^2 + n^2 = 3` and `m * n = 1`, and that they are the roots of the quadratic equation `x^2 + p*x + q = 0`. Our goal is to evaluate the expression `m^3 - (√5 - 1)m^2 - (√5 - 1)m + 1994`.

First, we determine the value of the sum `m + n`. We use the algebraic identity `(m + n)^2 = m^2 + n^2 + 2mn`. Substituting the given values `m^2 + n^2 = 3` and `mn = 1`, we obtain:
`(m + n)^2 = 3 + 2(1) = 5`.
Since `m` and `n` are positive, their sum `m + n` must also be positive. Therefore, taking the positive square root, we conclude that `m + n = √5`.

Next, we determine the value of the coefficient `p`. Since `m` and `n` are roots of `x^2 + px + q = 0`, they satisfy the equations:
1. `m^2 + pm + q = 0`
2. `n^2 + pn + q = 0`

Subtracting the second equation from the first, we get:
`(m^2 - n^2) + (pm - pn) = 0`
Factoring this expression yields:
`(m - n)(m + n) + p(m - n) = 0`
`(m - n)(m + n + p) = 0`

This implies that either `m - n = 0` or `m + n + p = 0`.
Let us consider the case `m - n = 0`, so `m = n`. From `mn = 1` and `m > 0`, we get `m^2 = 1`, which implies `m = 1`. Thus, `n = 1` as well. However, this would mean `m^2 + n^2 = 1^2 + 1^2 = 2`, which contradicts the given condition `m^2 + n^2 = 3`. Therefore, this case is impossible.

We must conclude that the other case, `m + n + p = 0`, holds. This gives us `p = -(m + n)`. Using our previously found result `m + n = √5`, we have `p = -√5`.

Now, we find the value of `q`. According to Vieta's formulas, for a quadratic equation `x^2 + px + q = 0`, the product of the roots is `q`. Thus, `q = mn`. Given `mn = 1`, we find that `q = 1`.

So, `m` is a root of the equation `x^2 - √5 * x + 1 = 0`. This means `m^2 - √5 * m + 1 = 0`.
From this equation, we can express `m^3` in terms of lower powers of `m`. Multiplying `m^2 + pm + q = 0` by `m` gives `m^3 + pm^2 + qm = 0`, so `m^3 = -pm^2 - qm`.

Let the expression to be evaluated be `E`. We substitute `m^3 = -pm^2 - qm` into `E`:
`E = m^3 - (√5 - 1)m^2 - (√5 - 1)m + 1994`
`E = (-pm^2 - qm) - (√5 - 1)m^2 - (√5 - 1)m + 1994`

Now, substitute the determined values `p = -√5` and `q = 1`:
`E = (-(-√5)m^2 - 1*m) - (√5 - 1)m^2 - (√5 - 1)m + 1994`
`E = √5 * m^2 - m - (√5 - 1)m^2 - (√5 - 1)m + 1994`

Grouping terms by powers of `m`:
`E = (√5 - (√5 - 1))m^2 + (-1 - (√5 - 1))m + 1994`
`E = (√5 - √5 + 1)m^2 + (-1 - √5 + 1)m + 1994`
`E = 1 * m^2 - √5 * m + 1994`
`E = m^2 - √5 * m + 1994`

From the equation `m^2 - √5 * m + 1 = 0`, we have `m^2 - √5 * m = -1`.
Substituting this into our simplified expression for `E`:
`E = -1 + 1994 = 1993`

Thus, the value of the polynomial is 1993.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- II. (30 points) Given positive numbers $m, n$ are the roots of the quadratic equation $x^{2}+$ $p x+q=0$, and $m^{2}+n^{2}=3, m n=1$. Find the value of the polynomial $x^{3}-(\sqrt{5}-1) x^{2}-(\sqrt{5}-1) x+1994$. -/
theorem algebra_312059 {p q : ℝ} (m n : ℝ) (hm : 0 < m) (hn : 0 < n)
    (hroots : m^2 + p * m + q = 0 ∧ n^2 + p * n + q = 0) (hsum : m^2 + n^2 = 3) (hprod : m * n = 1) :
    m^3 - (Real.sqrt 5 - 1) * m^2 - (Real.sqrt 5 - 1) * m + 1994 = 1993 := by
formal_proof:
import Mathlib

theorem algebra_312059 {p q : ℝ} (m n : ℝ) (hm : 0 < m) (hn : 0 < n)
    (hroots : m^2 + p * m + q = 0 ∧ n^2 + p * n + q = 0) (hsum : m^2 + n^2 = 3) (hprod : m * n = 1) :
    m^3 - (Real.sqrt 5 - 1) * m^2 - (Real.sqrt 5 - 1) * m + 1994 = 1993 := by

  have h1 : m + n = Real.sqrt 5 := by
    have h2 : m^2 + n^2 = 3 := hsum
    have h3 : m * n = 1 := hprod
    have h4 : (m + n)^2 = m^2 + n^2 + 2 * (m * n) := by ring
    rw [h2, h3] at h4
    have h5 : (m + n)^2 = 5 := by linarith
    have h6 : m + n > 0 := by nlinarith
    have h7 : m + n = Real.sqrt 5 := by
      have h8 : (Real.sqrt 5 : ℝ) ^ 2 = 5 := Real.sq_sqrt (by norm_num)
      have h9 : (m + n) ^ 2 = (Real.sqrt 5) ^ 2 := by linarith [h5, h8]
      have h10 : 0 ≤ Real.sqrt 5 := Real.sqrt_nonneg 5
      have h11 : 0 ≤ m + n := by linarith [h6]
      have h12 : m + n = Real.sqrt 5 := by
        nlinarith [Real.sqrt_nonneg 5, h9, h6]
      exact h12
    exact h7

  have hp : p = -(m + n) := by
    have h1 := hroots.1
    have h2 := hroots.2
    have eq1 : m^2 + p * m + q = 0 := h1
    have eq2 : n^2 + p * n + q = 0 := h2
    have eq3 : m^2 + p * m + q - (n^2 + p * n + q) = 0 := by linarith
    have eq4 : m^2 - n^2 + p * (m - n) = 0 := by linarith
    have eq5 : (m - n) * (m + n + p) = 0 := by
      ring_nf at eq4 ⊢
      linarith

    cases' (mul_eq_zero.mp eq5) with h6 h7
    · -- Case where m - n = 0, so m = n
      have h8 : m = n := by linarith
      have h9 : m * n = 1 := hprod
      rw [show n = m by linarith [h8]] at h9
      have h10 : m^2 = 1 := by nlinarith
      have h11 : m = 1 := by nlinarith
      have h12 : n = 1 := by nlinarith [h8, h11]
      have h13 : m + n = 2 := by linarith
      nlinarith [Real.sqrt_pos.mpr (show (0 : ℝ) < 5 by norm_num : (0 : ℝ) < 5), Real.sq_sqrt (show (0 : ℝ) ≤ (5 : ℝ) by norm_num : (0 : ℝ) ≤ (5 : ℝ)), hprod, h13, h1]
    · -- Case where m + n + p = 0
      linarith

  have hp_eq : p = -Real.sqrt 5 := by
    have h11 : p = -(m + n) := hp
    have h12 : m + n = Real.sqrt 5 := h1
    rw [h12] at h11
    linarith

  have hq_eq : q = 1 := by
    have h1 := hroots.1
    rw [show p = - (m + n) by linarith [hp]] at h1
    nlinarith [Real.sqrt_pos.mpr (show (0 : ℝ) < 5 by norm_num : (0 : ℝ) < 5), Real.sq_sqrt (show (0 : ℝ) ≤ (5 : ℝ) by norm_num : (0 : ℝ) ≤ (5 : ℝ)), hprod]

  have h_eq1 : m^2 + p * m + q = 0 := hroots.1
  have h_eq2 : m^3 = -p * m^2 - q * m := by
    have h_eq3 : m^3 + p * m^2 + q * m = 0 := by
      have h_eq4 : m^2 + p * m + q = 0 := h_eq1
      have h_eq5 : m * (m^2 + p * m + q) = 0 := by nlinarith
      nlinarith
    nlinarith

  have eq1 : m^3 - (Real.sqrt 5 - 1) * m^2 - (Real.sqrt 5 - 1) * m + 1994 = -p * m^2 - q * m - (Real.sqrt 5 - 1) * m^2 - (Real.sqrt 5 - 1) * m + 1994 := by
    rw [show m^3 = -p * m^2 - q * m by linarith [h_eq2]]
    
  rw [eq1]
  rw [show p = -Real.sqrt 5 by linarith [hp_eq]]
  rw [show q = 1 by linarith [hq_eq]]
  nlinarith [Real.sqrt_pos.mpr (show (0 : ℝ) < 5 by norm_num : (0 : ℝ) < 5), Real.sq_sqrt (show (0 : ℝ) ≤ (5 : ℝ) by norm_num : (0 : ℝ) ≤ (5 : ℝ)), hprod, Real.sqrt_nonneg 5, sq_nonneg (m - n)]

soln_description:
Answer: yes.

The idea is to define the partial sums instead as follows. Let $d(n)$ denote the divisor function. Let $s_{N}$ be suitably large, then define by downwards recursion

$$
s_{n}=s_{n+1}-d\left(s_{n+1}\right)
$$

with $N$ set such that $s_{0}=1$. Then $s_{k}=a_{1}+\cdots+a_{k}$ works fine.

All we need is to ensure this sequence stays positive. But $x-d(x) \geq x / 2$ for $x \geq 8$, so it's enough to take $s_{N}=2^{103}$.
informal_statement: Do there exist positive integers $a_{1}, \ldots, a_{100}$ such that for each $k=1, \ldots, 100$, the number $a_{1}+\cdots+a_{k}$ has exactly $a_{k}$ divisors?
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- Do there exist positive integers $a_{1}, \ldots, a_{100}$ such that for each $k=1, \ldots, 100$, the number $a_{1}+\cdots+a_{k}$ has exactly $a_{k}$ divisors? -/
theorem number_theory_259605 :
    ∃ a : Fin 100 → ℕ,
      (∀ i, 0 < a i) ∧
      (∀ k, (Finset.sum (Finset.univ.filter (· ≤ k)) fun i => a i).divisors.card = a k) := by

soln_description:
1. **Rewrite the given equation using trigonometric identities:**

   The given equation is:
   \[
   \left(\frac{3}{4} - \sin^2(\alpha)\right)\left(\frac{3}{4} - \sin^2(3\alpha)\right)\left(\frac{3}{4} - \sin^2(3^2\alpha)\right)\left(\frac{3}{4} - \sin^2(3^3\alpha)\right) = \frac{1}{256}
   \]

2. **Use the identity for \(\sin^2(x)\):**

   Recall that \(\sin^2(x) = \frac{1 - \cos(2x)}{2}\). Therefore:
   \[
   \frac{3}{4} - \sin^2(x) = \frac{3}{4} - \frac{1 - \cos(2x)}{2} = \frac{3}{4} - \frac{1}{2} + \frac{\cos(2x)}{2} = \frac{1}{4} + \frac{\cos(2x)}{2}
   \]

3. **Simplify each term:**

   Applying the above identity to each term:
   \[
   \frac{3}{4} - \sin^2(\alpha) = \frac{1}{4} + \frac{\cos(2\alpha)}{2}
   \]
   \[
   \frac{3}{4} - \sin^2(3\alpha) = \frac{1}{4} + \frac{\cos(6\alpha)}{2}
   \]
   \[
   \frac{3}{4} - \sin^2(9\alpha) = \frac{1}{4} + \frac{\cos(18\alpha)}{2}
   \]
   \[
   \frac{3}{4} - \sin^2(27\alpha) = \frac{1}{4} + \frac{\cos(54\alpha)}{2}
   \]

4. **Combine the terms:**

   The product of these terms is:
   \[
   \left(\frac{1}{4} + \frac{\cos(2\alpha)}{2}\right)\left(\frac{1}{4} + \frac{\cos(6\alpha)}{2}\right)\left(\frac{1}{4} + \frac{\cos(18\alpha)}{2}\right)\left(\frac{1}{4} + \frac{\cos(54\alpha)}{2}\right) = \frac{1}{256}
   \]

5. **Simplify the equation:**

   Notice that \(\frac{1}{256} = \left(\frac{1}{4}\right)^4\). Therefore, each term must be equal to \(\frac{1}{4}\):
   \[
   \frac{1}{4} + \frac{\cos(2\alpha)}{2} = \frac{1}{4}
   \]
   \[
   \frac{1}{4} + \frac{\cos(6\alpha)}{2} = \frac{1}{4}
   \]
   \[
   \frac{1}{4} + \frac{\cos(18\alpha)}{2} = \frac{1}{4}
   \]
   \[
   \frac{1}{4} + \frac{\cos(54\alpha)}{2} = \frac{1}{4}
   \]

6. **Solve for \(\alpha\):**

   Each equation simplifies to:
   \[
   \frac{\cos(2\alpha)}{2} = 0 \implies \cos(2\alpha) = 0 \implies 2\alpha = 90^\circ \implies \alpha = 45^\circ
   \]

   However, we need to find the least positive angle \(\alpha\) such that:
   \[
   \sin(81\alpha) = \sin(\alpha)
   \]

   This implies:
   \[
   81\alpha = 180^\circ k + \alpha \quad \text{or} \quad 81\alpha = 180^\circ k - \alpha
   \]

   For the smallest positive \(\alpha\):
   \[
   81\alpha = 180^\circ + \alpha \implies 80\alpha = 180^\circ \implies \alpha = \frac{180^\circ}{80} = \frac{9^\circ}{4}
   \]

7. **Express \(\alpha\) in simplest form:**

   \(\alpha = \frac{9}{4}^\circ\). In degrees, this is \(\frac{9}{4}\).

8. **Find \(m + n\):**

   Here, \(m = 9\) and \(n = 4\). Therefore, \(m + n = 9 + 4 = 13\).

The final answer is \(\boxed{13}\).
informal_statement: The least positive angle $\alpha$ for which $$\left(\frac34-\sin^2(\alpha)\right)\left(\frac34-\sin^2(3\alpha)\right)\left(\frac34-\sin^2(3^2\alpha)\right)\left(\frac34-\sin^2(3^3\alpha)\right)=\frac1{256}$$ has a degree measure of $\tfrac{m}{n}$, where $m$ and $n$ are relatively prime positive integers. Find $m+n$.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

open Real Set
open scoped Real

/- The least positive angle $\alpha$ for which $$\left(\frac34-\sin^2(\alpha)\right)\left(\frac34-\sin^2(3\alpha)\right)\left(\frac34-\sin^2(3^2\alpha)\right)\left(\frac34-\sin^2(3^3\alpha)\right)=\frac1{256}$$ has a degree measure of $\tfrac{m}{n}$, where $m$ and $n$ are relatively prime positive integers. Find $m+n$. -/
theorem algebra_56460 {α : ℝ} (hα : α > 0) :
    (3/4 - sin α^2) * (3/4 - sin (3*α)^2) * (3/4 - sin (3^2*α)^2) *
    (3/4 - sin (3^3*α)^2) = 1/256 ↔ α = 13/180 * π := by

soln_description:
1. **Claim:** If \( f^n(r) = 0 \), then the value of \( x \) which satisfies \( f(x) = r \) will also satisfy \( f^{n+1}(x) = 0 \).

   **Proof:** We have 
   \[
   f^{n+1}(x) = f^n(f(x)) = f^n(r) = 0.
   \]
   It now suffices to prove that there's always a real solution to \( f(x) = r \), which occurs if and only if the discriminant is non-negative.

2. **Discriminant Calculation:**
   The quadratic equation \( f(x) = r \) can be written as:
   \[
   x^2 + 2007x + (1 - r) = 0.
   \]
   The discriminant \(\Delta\) of this quadratic equation is given by:
   \[
   \Delta = 2007^2 - 4 \cdot 1 \cdot (1 - r) = 2007^2 + 4(r - 1).
   \]
   For the quadratic equation to have real solutions, the discriminant must be non-negative:
   \[
   2007^2 + 4(r - 1) \ge 0.
   \]
   Simplifying this inequality, we get:
   \[
   r \ge \frac{4 - 2007^2}{4}.
   \]

3. **Finding a Solution to \( f(x) = 0 \):**
   Consider the quadratic equation \( f(x) = x^2 + 2007x + 1 = 0 \). The solutions to this equation are:
   \[
   x = \frac{-2007 \pm \sqrt{2007^2 - 4}}{2}.
   \]
   One of these solutions is:
   \[
   x = \frac{-2007 + \sqrt{2007^2 - 4}}{2}.
   \]
   Since \( 2007^2 - 4 \) is a large positive number, the square root term is slightly less than \( 2007 \), making \( x \) slightly greater than \(-1\).

4. **Induction Hypothesis:**
   We now use induction to make the claim that if \( r > -1 \) satisfies \( f^n(r) = 0 \) for some positive integer \( n \), then there exists a real \( x > -1 \) such that \( f(x) = r \).

   **Proof:** One \( x \) that satisfies \( x^2 + 2007x + 1 - r = 0 \) is:
   \[
   x = \frac{-2007 + \sqrt{2007^2 + 4r - 4}}{2}.
   \]
   This \( x \) is obviously real and greater than \(-1\) for any \( r > -1 \).

5. **Conclusion:**
   Hence, if we use the first claim, this second claim shows that because one of the roots to \( f(x) \) is greater than \(-1\), there will always be a real root greater than \(-1\) to \( f^n(x) \) for all positive integers \( n \). Therefore, \( r > -1 \ge \frac{4 - 2007^2}{4} \), which is what we wanted to show.

\(\blacksquare\)
informal_statement: Let $ f(x) \equal{} x^2 \plus{} 2007x \plus{} 1$. Prove that for every positive integer $ n$, the equation $ \underbrace{f(f(\ldots(f}_{n\ {\rm times}}(x))\ldots)) \equal{} 0$ has at least one real solution.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

open Real

/- Let $ f(x) \equal{} x^2 \plus{} 2007x \plus{} 1$. Prove that for every positive integer $ n$, the equation $ \underbrace{f(f(\ldots(f}_{n\ {\rm times}}(x))\ldots)) \equal{} 0$ has at least one real solution. -/
theorem calculus_36805 {f : ℝ → ℝ} (hf : f = fun x => x ^ 2 + 2007 * x + 1) :
    ∀ n > 0, ∃ x, f^[n] x = 0 := by

soln_description:
Let's start by writing down the domain of the equation: $\sin x>0, \cos x>0$. Convert the logarithm on the right side to the base $\sin x: 2-\log _{\sin x} \cos x=1 / \log _{\sin x} \cos x$. After transformations, we get:

$$
\left(\log _{\sin x} \cos x-1\right)^{2}=0 \text { or } \log _{\sin x} \cos x=1
$$

After exponentiation, we will have:

$$
\cos x=\sin x, x=\pi / 4+k \pi \text {. }
$$

Among the obtained values, only solutions of the form $x=\pi / 4+2 k \pi, k \in Z$ satisfy the domain.

## Answer

$x=\pi / 4+2 k \pi, k \in Z$.
informal_statement: Solve the equation $2-\log _{\sin x} \cos x=\log _{\cos x} \sin x$.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

open Real Set
open scoped BigOperators

/- Solve the equation $2-\log _{\sin x} \cos x=\log _{\cos x} \sin x$. -/
theorem algebra_228815 {x : ℝ} (hx : sin x > 0 ∧ cos x > 0) :
    2 - logb (sin x) (cos x) = logb (cos x) (sin x) ↔
    ∃ k : ℤ, x = π / 4 + 2 * k * π := by

informal_statement: 10. The number of positive integer pairs $(a, b)$ that satisfy $a b^{2}=6^{10}$ is $\qquad$ pairs.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- 10. The number of positive integer pairs $(a, b)$ that satisfy $a b^{2}=6^{10}$ is $\qquad$ pairs. -/
theorem number_theory_123451 :
    {(a, b) : ℕ × ℕ | a > 0 ∧ b > 0 ∧ a * b ^ 2 = 6 ^ 10}.ncard = 36 := by

soln_description:
Answer: 156.

Solution: Note that $P+B+\Gamma \geq 3$ and $\leq 24$ (since the digits are different). Moreover, the numbers $\overline{P B \Gamma}$ and $(P + B + \Gamma)$ should give the same remainder when divided by 9. This is only possible when $P+B+\Gamma$ is a multiple of 3. Note that $P+B+\Gamma=9$ does not work, since $(P + B + \Gamma) \times (P+B+\Gamma+1)=90$ is a two-digit number. By trying $12,15,18,21,24$, we get $\overline{P B \Gamma}=$ $156=12 \times 13$.
informal_statement: 6. Find all three-digit numbers $\overline{\Pi B \Gamma}$, consisting of distinct digits П, B, and Г, for which the equality $\overline{\Pi B \Gamma}=(П+B+\Gamma) \times(П+B+\Gamma+1)$ holds.
informal_proof:
We are given that P, B, and G are distinct digits that satisfy the equation $100 \cdot P + 10 \cdot B + G = (P + B + G) \cdot (P + B + G + 1)$. The constraints on the digits are:
1. P, B, and G are distinct natural numbers.
2. $1 \le P \le 9$.
3. $0 \le B \le 9$.
4. $0 \le G \le 9$.

The proof proceeds by an exhaustive case analysis, checking every possible combination of values for P, B, and G that fall within these ranges. There are 9 possible values for P (from 1 to 9), 10 for B (from 0 to 9), and 10 for G (from 0 to 9), resulting in a total of $9 \times 10 \times 10 = 900$ combinations to check.

For each specific assignment of values to (P, B, G), we verify if it satisfies both the distinctness condition and the given equation. This systematic verification shows that there is only one such combination.

Let's test the proposed solution, `P = 1`, `B = 5`, `G = 6`:
- **Distinctness:** The digits 1, 5, and 6 are all distinct from one another, so this condition is met.
- **Equation:**
  - The left-hand side is $100 \cdot 1 + 10 \cdot 5 + 6 = 100 + 50 + 6 = 156$.
  - The right-hand side is $(1 + 5 + 6) \cdot (1 + 5 + 6 + 1) = 12 \cdot 13 = 156$.
Since both sides are equal, the equation holds. Thus, `P = 1, B = 5, G = 6` is a valid solution.

Let's consider another example, such as `P = 1, B = 0, G = 2`:
- **Distinctness:** The digits 1, 0, and 2 are distinct.
- **Equation:**
  - The left-hand side is $100 \cdot 1 + 10 \cdot 0 + 2 = 102$.
  - The right-hand side is $(1 + 0 + 2) \cdot (1 + 0 + 2 + 1) = 3 \cdot 4 = 12$.
Since $102 \neq 12$, this combination is not a solution.

Another example is `P = 2, B = 3, G = 2`:
- **Distinctness:** Here, `P = G = 2`, which violates the condition that the digits must be distinct. Therefore, this is not a solution.

By carrying out this check for all 900 possible combinations, we find that every combination other than `(1, 5, 6)` either violates the distinctness condition or fails to satisfy the numerical equation. Therefore, the only possible values are `P = 1`, `B = 5`, and `G = 6`.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- 6. Find all three-digit numbers $\overline{\Pi B \Gamma}$, consisting of distinct digits П, B, and Г, for which the equality $\overline{\Pi B \Gamma}=(П+B+\Gamma) \times(П+B+\Gamma+1)$ holds. -/
theorem number_theory_194462 (P B G : ℕ) (h₀ : P ≠ B) (h₁ : P ≠ G) (h₂ : B ≠ G)
    (h₃ : 1 ≤ P ∧ P ≤ 9) (h₄ : 0 ≤ B ∧ B ≤ 9) (h₅ : 0 ≤ G ∧ G ≤ 9)
    (h₆ : 100 * P + 10 * B + G = (P + B + G) * (P + B + G + 1)) :
    P = 1 ∧ B = 5 ∧ G = 6 := by
formal_proof:
import Mathlib

theorem number_theory_194462 (P B G : ℕ) (h₀ : P ≠ B) (h₁ : P ≠ G) (h₂ : B ≠ G)
    (h₃ : 1 ≤ P ∧ P ≤ 9) (h₄ : 0 ≤ B ∧ B ≤ 9) (h₅ : 0 ≤ G ∧ G ≤ 9)
    (h₆ : 100 * P + 10 * B + G = (P + B + G) * (P + B + G + 1)) :
    P = 1 ∧ B = 5 ∧ G = 6 := by 
  rcases h₃ with ⟨h₃₁, h₃₂⟩
  rcases h₄ with ⟨h₄₁, h₄₂⟩
  rcases h₅ with ⟨h₅₁, h₅₂⟩
  interval_cases P <;> interval_cases B <;> interval_cases G
  <;> omega

soln_description:
Question 216, Solution: First, we prove that for any non-negative integer $n$, the interval $\left(5^{n}, 5^{n+1}\right)$ contains either two or three powers of 2.

If there exists a non-negative integer $n$ such that the interval $\left(5^{n}, 5^{n+1}\right)$ contains only one power of 2, let's say $2^{m}$, then $2^{m-1} \leq 5^{n}\frac{5^{n+1}}{5^{n}}=5$, which is impossible; if there exists a non-negative integer $n$ such that the interval $\left(5^{n}, 5^{n+1}\right)$ contains at least four powers of 2, let's say $5^{n}\frac{2^{m+3}}{2^{m}}=8$, which is also impossible. Therefore, the above statement is proven.

Returning to the original problem, according to the conditions, we know that $2^{2012}<2^{2013}<5^{867}<2^{2014}$. We need to find how many of the 867 intervals $\left(5^{0}, 5^{1}\right)$, $\left(5^{1}, 5^{2}\right), \cdots,\left(5^{866}, 5^{867}\right)$ contain exactly three powers of 2. Let's say there are $\mathrm{m}$ intervals that contain exactly three powers of 2, and $\mathrm{n}$ intervals that contain exactly two powers of 2. Then $\left\{\begin{array}{c}m+n=867 \\ 3 m+2 n=2013\end{array}\right.$, solving this gives $m=279$.
informal_statement: Question 216, Given $2^{2013}<5^{867}<2^{2014}$, how many integer pairs $(\mathrm{m}, \mathrm{n})$ satisfy: $5^{\mathrm{n}}<2^{\mathrm{m}}<$ $2^{\mathrm{m}+2}<5^{\mathrm{n}+1}$ ~ where $1 \leq \mathrm{m} \leq 2012$.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- Question 216, Given $2^{2013}<5^{867}<2^{2014}$, how many integer pairs $(\mathrm{m}, \mathrm{n})$ satisfy: $5^{\mathrm{n}}<2^{\mathrm{m}}<$ $2^{\mathrm{m}+2}<5^{\mathrm{n}+1}$ ~ where $1 \leq \mathrm{m} \leq 2012$. -/
theorem number_theory_211158 :
    Set.ncard {p : ℕ × ℕ | p.1 ∈ Finset.Icc 1 2012 ∧ p.2 > 0 ∧ 5^p.2 < 2^p.1 ∧ 2^(p.1 + 2) < 5^(p.2 + 1)} = 279 := by

soln_description: We show that the square root is D = 6...68 (with n-1 6s). We have D = 6(10 n - 1)/9 + 2 = (2/3)(10 n + 2), so D 2 = (4/9)(10 2n + 4·10 n + 4) = (4/9)(10 2n - 1) + 2(8/9)(10 n - 1) + 4 = A + 2B + 4. 7th Junior Balkan 2003 © John Scholes jscholes@kalva.demon.co.uk 3 Dec 2003 Last corrected/updated 3 Dec 03
informal_statement: 7th Junior Balkan 2003 Problem 1 Let A = 44...4 (2n digits) and B = 88...8 (n digits). Show that A + 2B + 4 is a square.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- 7th Junior Balkan 2003 Problem 1 Let A = 44...4 (2n digits) and B = 88...8 (n digits). Show that A + 2B + 4 is a square. -/
theorem number_theory_139667 {n : ℕ} (A B : ℕ) (hA : A = ∑ i ∈ Finset.range (2 * n), 10 ^ i * 4)
    (hB : B = ∑ i ∈ Finset.range n, 10 ^ i * 8) :
    IsSquare (A + 2 * B + 4) := by

soln_description:
(a) According to the definition of the Cantor Set, we have the following drawings:

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2024_05_01_a444074f1f8ae50444d5g-19.jpg?height=225&width=721&top_left_y=1161&top_left_x=672)

(b) $1 / 3$ is an endpoint of $C_{2}$, so it belongs to the Cantor Set.

$3 / 81 = 1 / 27$ and $1 / 27$ is an endpoint of $C_{4}$, so $3 / 81$ belongs to the Cantor Set.

$4 / 9$ is between $1 / 3$ and $2 / 3$, so it is in the middle third of $C_{1}$ and is removed from $C_{2}$. Therefore, $4 / 9$ does not belong to the Cantor Set.

$4 / 81$ is between $1 / 27$ and $2 / 27$, and thus is in the middle third of $C_{3}$ and is removed from $C_{4}$. Therefore, $4 / 81$ does not belong to the Cantor Set.

(c) Let's try to find a pattern for the lengths of the segments. For example, $C_{1}$ has a length of 1 and $C_{2}$ has a length of $2 / 3$. Does this already provide a pattern, where the numerator is obtained by multiplying by 2 and the denominator by 3, or in other words by $2 / 3$?

Now, $C_{3}$ has a length of $4 / 9$, $C_{4}$ has a length of $8 / 27$, and $C_{5}$ has a length of $16 / 81$. Therefore, the length of $C_{n}$ is $\left(\frac{2}{3}\right)^{n-1}$.

Note that the lengths of $C_{1}, C_{2}, C_{3}, \ldots, C_{n}, \ldots$, form a geometric progression with a common ratio $q = 2 / 3$ and the first term $a_{1} = 1$.

$$
1, \frac{2}{3},\left(\frac{2}{3}\right)^{2},\left(\frac{2}{3}\right)^{3},\left(\frac{2}{3}\right)^{4}, \ldots,\left(\frac{2}{3}\right)^{n}, \ldots
$$

## List 4
informal_statement:
Draw a line segment of length 1, and denote it by $C_{1}$. Remove the middle third (without removing the endpoints). Denote by $C_{2}$ what remains. Now, remove the middle third (without the endpoints) of each line segment of $C_{2}$. Denote by $C_{3}$ what remains. We can continue this process, at each stage removing the middle third of each segment in $C_{n}$ to form $C_{n+1}$.

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2024_05_01_a444074f1f8ae50444d5g-04.jpg?height=193&width=721&top_left_y=294&top_left_x=672)

(a) Draw $C_{1}, C_{2}$, and $C_{3}$, indicating the numbers at the endpoints of the segments.

(b) Which of the following points belong to the Cantor set? $\frac{1}{3}, \frac{4}{9}, \frac{3}{81}, \frac{4}{81}$.

(c) What are the lengths of $C_{3}, C_{4}$, and $C_{5}$? Can you find an expression for the length of $C_{n}$?

## List 4
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

open Real

/- Draw a line segment of length 1, and denote it by $C_{1}$. Remove the middle third (without removing the endpoints). Denote by $C_{2}$ what remains. Now, remove the middle third (without the endpoints) of each line segment of $C_{2}$. Denote by $C_{3}$ what remains. We can continue this process, at each stage removing the middle third of each segment in $C_{n}$ to form $C_{n+1}$.

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2024_05_01_a444074f1f8ae50444d5g-04.jpg?height=193&width=721&top_left_y=294&top_left_x=672)

(a) Draw $C_{1}, C_{2}$, and $C_{3}$, indicating the numbers at the endpoints of the segments.

(b) Which of the following points belong to the Cantor set? $\frac{1}{3}, \frac{4}{9}, \frac{3}{81}, \frac{4}{81}$.

(c) What are the lengths of $C_{3}, C_{4}$, and $C_{5}$? Can you find an expression for the length of $C_{n}$?

## List 4 -/
theorem number_theory_242762 {C : ℕ → ℝ}
    (hC1 : C 1 = 1)
    (hC2 : C 2 = C 1 - (1 / 3) * C 1)
    (hC3 : C 3 = C 2 - (1 / 3) * C 2)
    (hC : ∀ n, C (n + 1) = C n - (1 / 3) * C n) :
    C 1 = 1 ∧ C 2 = 2 / 3 ∧ C 3 = 4 / 9 ∧ C 4 = 8 / 27 ∧ C 5 = 16 / 81 ∧
    ∀ n, C n = (2 / 3) ^ (n - 1) := by

soln_description:
Prove using the Cauchy inequality:
$$\left(a^{4}+b^{2} c^{2}+b^{2} c^{2}\right)(a+b+c)(a+c+b) \geqslant\left(a^{2}+2 b c\right)^{3}$$

Similarly, there are other two inequalities, thus
$$\sum \sqrt{\frac{a^{4}+2 b^{2} c^{2}}{a^{2}+2 b c}} \geqslant \sum \frac{a^{2}+2 b c}{a+b+c}=a+b+c$$

Adding them up proves the original problem! Finding some approximate quantities and using important inequalities for some bounds is also a common method.
For example, if $A \approx B$, and $A \geqslant B$, then
$$\frac{\sqrt{A}}{\sqrt{B}}=\frac{A}{\sqrt{A B}} \geqslant \frac{2 A}{A+B}=\frac{\sqrt{A B}}{B} \leqslant \frac{A+B}{2 B}$$

Here, $A \approx B$ means that when the variables take the values for which the inequality holds with equality, we have $A=B$. We are not limited to using the $\mathrm{AM}-\mathrm{GM}$ inequality for $A, B$, but can also consider important inequalities like Cauchy.
informal_statement:
Example $4.20$ Given $a, b, c > 0$, prove that
$$\sqrt{\frac{a^{4}+2 b^{2} c^{2}}{a^{2}+2 b c}}+\sqrt{\frac{b^{4}+2 c^{2} a^{2}}{b^{2}+2 c a}}+\sqrt{\frac{c^{4}+2 a^{2} b^{2}}{c^{2}+2 a b}} \geqslant a+b+c$$
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

open Real

/- Example $4.20$ Given $a, b, c > 0$, prove that
$$\sqrt{\frac{a^{4}+2 b^{2} c^{2}}{a^{2}+2 b c}}+\sqrt{\frac{b^{4}+2 c^{2} a^{2}}{b^{2}+2 c a}}+\sqrt{\frac{c^{4}+2 a^{2} b^{2}}{c^{2}+2 a b}} \geqslant a+b+c$$ -/
theorem inequalities_600780 (a b c : ℝ) (ha : 0 < a) (hb : 0 < b) (hc : 0 < c) :
    sqrt ((a^4 + 2 * b^2 * c^2) / (a^2 + 2 * b * c)) +
    sqrt ((b^4 + 2 * c^2 * a^2) / (b^2 + 2 * c * a)) +
    sqrt ((c^4 + 2 * a^2 * b^2) / (c^2 + 2 * a * b)) ≥ a + b + c := by

/- A polynomial with integer coefficients is of the form
\[x^3 + a_2 x^2 + a_1 x - 11 = 0.\]Enter all the possible integer roots of this polynomial, separated by commas. -/
theorem algebra_12538 (a : ℕ → ℤ) (h : ∀ x : ℤ, x^3 + a 2 * x^2 + a 1 * x - 11 = 0 →
    x = -11 ∨ x = -1 ∨ x = 1 ∨ x = 11) :
    {x : ℤ | x^3 + a 2 * x^2 + a 1 * x - 11 = 0} = {-11, -1, 1, 11} := by

soln_description:
Take $a=0, b=1$, then we have $\operatorname{arctg} a+\operatorname{arctg} b$ $=\frac{\pi}{4}$,
(B) and
(D) both fit. Then take $a=-3$,
$b=-2$, then we have arctg $x+\operatorname{arctg} \dot{b}=-\frac{3 \pi}{4}$,
only (D) fits, so the answer is (D).
